title.narrative: COVID-19 Hållbara lösningar för avfallshantering CXB
COVID-19 Sustainable Solutions to Solid Waste CXB

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 UNDP:s landskontor i Bangladesh har ansökt om finansiering för att utföra insatsen "Hållbara lösningar för avfallshantering: en lokal respons på Rohingya-krisen i Bangladesh" under perioden 2018–2021.
Insatsen syftar till att utveckla och genomföra ett hållbart avfallshanteringssystem för att bidra till förbättrad miljö, hälsa, vattenkvalitet, sanitet, återvinning, försörjning, social sammanhållning och mänsklig värdighet inom områden av Cox Bazar som påverkas av flyktingkrisen.
Projektet har två övergripande resultat:
1. Utveckla ett hållbart avfallshanteringssystem: Utsatta människor från flykting- och värdsamhällen har förbättrad tillgång till lämplig avfallshantering och infrastruktur, och lever i renare, friskare och mer humana förhållanden.
2. Förändra beteenden och attityder: Lokala avfallshanteringsmetoder och beteenden förändras till det bättre och blir mer miljö-och hälsomedvetna, för att skapa en hållbar förändring i hur avfall i området uppkommer, lagras och hanteras.
UNDP kommer tillsammans med sina partners (icke-statliga organisationer och lokala myndigheter) att genomföra insatsen. Projektet kommer att knyta innovativa avfallshanteringsmetoder till mål inom miljö, hälsa, vatten och sanitet, lägerplanering och skydd (enligt den gemensamma handlingsplanen för Rohingya-krisen och de globala utvecklingsmålen), med betydande resultat för försörjningsmöjligheter, social sammanhållning, jämlikhet, och mänsklig värdighet i Cox Bazar.
Detta kommer att ske genom en stegvis implementering för att effektivt möta angelägna och brådskande behov av avfallshantering på kort sikt. Parallellt kommer projektet att engagera flyktingar och människor i värdsamhällen samt statliga myndigheter för att utforma och utveckla långsiktiga återvinningsaktiviteter för att expandera den lokala ekonomin inom avfall och generera försörjningsmöjligheter och inkomster för lokalbefolkningen. Detta i enlighet med visionen i den gemensamma handlingsplanen för Rohingya-krisen, som säger att ”i det nuvarande stadiet kommer avfallshantering stödjas av kontantbaserade aktiviteter för insamling av avfall, [medan längre fram] kommer ett avfallshanteringssystem att etableras vilket inkluderar installation, drift och underhåll av en gemensam deponi". Hushåll, och särskilt kvinnor, kommer att engageras, eftersom det är på hushålls-och familjenivå som det mesta av avfallet produceras, och det är där som lösningar måste tillämpas.
Konstruktion av ny infrastruktur och stöd till återvinningsföretag förväntas omvandla befintliga avfallshanteringsalternativ på lokal nivå. När lönsamma incitament för hushållsåtervinning och avfallshantering införs kommer det leda till förändringar i beteende, avfallshantering och återvinningsmönster. Detta kommer att förbättra lokal miljö och hälsa för alla människor i drabbade samhällen, reducera potentiella föroreningskällor och faror för både vattenförsörjning, det fysiska landskapet och luften (genom att minska förbränning av sopor) samtidigt som det ger extra fördelar för lokal ekonomi.
UNDP och partners kommer med denna insats att visa hur avfall kan omvandlas till positiva fördelar och försörjningsmöjligheter. Återvinning och återanvändning av avfall kan vara en lukrativ industri med transformativ potential för utsatta människor och samhällen. Detta kommer att uppmuntra människor i både värdsamhällen och flyktingläger att se avfall som en potentiell resurs. Förbättringar av avfallshantering och en renare miljö är synliga och påtagliga förbättringar av förhållandena för lokalsamhällen och kan bidra till att stärka den sociala sammanhållningen.
Insatsens totala budget är 4 879 764 USD (cirka 45 miljoner kronor). Sida finansierar 100% av den totala projektbudgeten.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 UNDP's Country office in Bangladesh has applied to Sida for financing to carry out the intervention "Sustainable Solutions to Solid Waste: A Local Response to the Rohingya crisis in Bangladesh" during the period 2018-2021.
The intervention aims to develop and implement a Solid Waste Management strategy to contribute to improved environment, health, water quality, sanitation, recycling, livelihoods and human dignity in areas of Cox's bazar District affected by the Rohingya refugee crisis.
The project has two outcomes:
1. Developing Waste Management Systems: Vulnerable people from refugee and host communities have enhanced access to appropriate waste management services and infrastructure, and live in cleaner, healthier and more humane conditions.
2. Changing Behaviours and Attitudes: Local waste management behaviours and practices reformed to be more environmentally and health conscious, to prompt a sustainable change in how waste in the affected regions is created, stored and managed.
UNDP together with its implementing partners (NGOs and Local Government agencies) will implement the intervention. UNDP’s proposed project will tie innovative solid waste activities to well-defined environmental, health, WASH, site management, and protection goals (both under the Joint Response Plan and the SDGs), with significant additional anticipated benefits to livelihoods, social cohesion, gender, and human dignity in Cox’s Bazar District.
This will be done through a deliberately phased approach, to respond effectively to pressing and urgent waste removal needs in the short-term. In parallel the project will engage refugees and people in host communities as well as government to design and develop longer-term recycling activities to expand and nurture a local economy for solid waste and generate livelihood benefits and income for local people. This is in line with the vision outlined in the Rohingya Joint Response Plan, which states that at the present “stage of the response, solid waste management programs will be supported by Cash-Based Interventions for waste collection, [while in time] a solid waste management system will be established including the installation, operation and maintenance of a shared landfill”. Households, including women, will be prominently engaged as the most critical local unit, as it is at the household and family level that much of the current waste is produced, and it is at this level that solutions must be applied.
The construction of new infrastructure and support to recycling enterprises is expected to transform the existing solid waste management options on the ground. When the profitable incentives for household recycling and waste disposal are adjusted, permanent changes in local behavior, waste disposal, recycling patterns, and effective waste management systems will result. This will improve the local environment and health for all people in affected communities, removing potential sources of toxins and danger to both the water supply, the physical landscape, and the air (by preventing the burning of trash), while providing added benefits to the local economy.
UNDP and partners are envisioned to show how waste can be turned into benefits and livelihoods development. Recycling and repurposing of solid waste can be a lucrative industry with transformative potential for vulnerable people and communities. These sorts of “trash-to-cash” activities will encourage local people in both host communities and refugee camps to view solid waste as a potential resource. Improvements to the management of waste, and a cleaner local landscape, are visible and demonstrable improvements in conditions for local communities, and can contribute to reinforce social cohesion.
The intervention’s total budget is 4 879 764 USD, approximately 45 million SEK. Sida will provide 100% of the total project budget.

The project has two key outcomes: Developing Waste Management Systems: Vulnerable people from refugee and host communities have enhanced access to appropriate waste management services and infrastructure, and live in cleaner, healthier and more humane conditions. Changing Behaviours and Attitudes: Local waste management behaviours and practices reformed to be more environmentally and health conscious, to prompt a sustainable change in how waste in the affected regions is created, stored and managed.

title.narrative: Sustainable Solutions to Solid Waste Cox's Bazar

description.narrative:
Highlights of results:
Outcome 1. Developing Waste Management Systems - a cleaning campaign in the refugee camps of Ukhia Upazila (megacamp) was conducted. A one-off cleaning campaign of solid waste was completed in 27 camps. 4,000 m3 waste was collected, 974 Rohingya workers engaged through Cash for Work (livelihood generation), 10,408 days of work created (labour/day) and 1,458 trips of trucks to the sanitary landfill conducted. Covid-19 orientation and protective measures ensured. - a Temporary Solid Waste Facility (sanitary landfill) for the Ukhia camps opened in Camp 20Ext. A sanitary landfill constructed for the 27 camps in Ukhia Upazila, to safely dispose the non-recyclable waste and reduce the burden of waste in the camps. Landfill was opened to the camps in October 2020 and a total of 4,000 m3 disposed waste, 15 livelihoods generated and environmental mitigation plan developed at that time. The landfill is only used for non-recyclable waste which accounts for 30% of the total waste generated in camps. Since then, 12 camps (44% of Ukhia camps) have been regularly using the landfill. - a Municipal Solid Waste collection system in Teknaf Municipality established. The municipal SWM system has been improved promoting waste segregation at source, covering approximately 2,000 HH (40% of the total) and 1,000 market shops (100% of the total), 2,338 m3 of waste collected, 25 livelihoods generated (60% women) and 1,798 kg of compost produced. Following a series of consultations with the target households, the project managed to succeed in initiating a cost recovery program for the solid waste management services. - an improved Temporary SW Facility in Teknaf Municipality has been constructed to mitigate the environmental impacts of the existing municipal dumping site and is fully functional since January 2021. The facility which has a capacity of 800 m3 has been completed with the construction of wash facilities (male & female latrines) and restroom for workers. The project has also completed the construction of twenty one secondary collection points in the five Unions and Teknaf Municipality. In addition, the extension work of the composting unit in Teknaf Municipality has been completed and officially inaugurated by the municipality. A total of five decentralized compost units have also been constructed to reduce the volume of waste to finally dispose and produce compost in the Unions Parishads.
Outcome 2. Behaviour change and attitudes - in Teknaf Municipality, households and shop owners now segregate waste at source level into organic and inorganic waste. Inorganic waste is collected by volunteers by vans and disposed of into secondary collection points, which are emptied by the municipality collectors with the municipal trucks and transported to the improved sanitary landfill. Recyclables are stored at the HH or shop and collected by the recycling entrepreneurs and/or segregated at the sanitary landfill by workers (Cash for Work). In Union Parishads, the SWM systems were established mainly to target the market stores and surrounding HH. Waste is collected at source and segregated into organic and inorganic. Inorganic waste is transported to the secondary collection points constructed in each market area. Recyclables are stored at the HH or shop and collected by the recycling entrepreneurs and/or segregated at the secondary collection point and linked with the recycling sector. Inorganic waste is disposed of into temporary disposal sites while waiting for permanent land. - a grant program to support the development of the recycling sector and creation of two associations of scrap dealers was developed. 60 scrap dealers identified, 36 dealers provided with basic training on way of segregation, sorting and value chain, as well as the use of safety and security equipment, 30 scrap dealers provided with Advance Business Plan Development training, 20 scrap dealers granted. 18% of increase income of grantees and 2,440 m3 recyclables collected. - increase of the business capacity of the local recycling sector in Teknaf and Ukhia. Seventeen out of twenty grantees (85%) have increased their monthly profit by 35% and increased the recyclables collected by 6% in volume since December 2020. Besides the grants, the project is building the capacity of the sector through the two Association of scrap dealers in Teknaf and Ukhia in the following areas: 1) Increased access to recyclables, 2) Integration/recognition of the recycling sector as part of the SWM systems in host communities and camps, 3) Better visibility and environmental and social principle compliance. - as a preparatory work of the Solid Waste Master plan, UNDP has conducted an SWM gap analysis to determine the technical, financial, legal gaps and resources of the local government. One of the key findings of the assessment is the need to activate and mobilize the SWM stakeholders (the counterparts in each project location and overall governance system) and provide key information on the SWM as preparatory work to the consultative process for the formulation and implementation of the Master plan. - activation of the SWM Governance system. Build a counterpart for SWM at the local government level and activated and mobilized the SWM stakeholders in Teknaf and Ukhia. Seven WATSAN Committee meetings organized at Union, Municipality and Upazila level, participated by 269 committee members.
Cross-cutting - Covid-19 response plan. Cash distribution to 2,558 households who received 8,953,000 BDT cash for food. 6,684 sets of hygiene items to households, market stores, 50 scrap dealers and 228 waste collectors. 5,964 persons attended Covid- 19 orientation sessions, 7,801 leaflets covering key Covid-19 messages, installation of 15 billboards, 134,116 people reached by sensitization messages and 7,600 beneficiaries received Covid-19 information based voice messages. - gender mainstreaming study conducted and a solid waste management gender strategy produced. Conducted a SWM Gender and child labour study, training to UNDP and implementing partner staff and field workers, as well as produced and published a strategic document and shared to the WASH Sector partners. - participation in the WASH Sector SWM working group agenda. UNDP is the main partner supporting the WASH sector on the SWM issues, providing technical advice and support in workshops, technical documents and coordination.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
